title: How to Construct a Shiplap Wall

parts.name: Preparing the Wall and the Shiplap

steps.headline: Build a wall, if necessary.
steps.description: If you want to install shiplap on an entirely new wall, it can be done. However, you will first need to frame the new wall, or hire a contractor to do so. Once you have the bare studs set up, you could just install shiplap boards on top of these. However, this sort of construction may or may not meet building codes or fire codes in your area. It will also be more difficult to insulate. Alternatively, install drywall or plywood over the bare studs, then shiplap boards on top of that. Note that plywood creates a better surface to nail the shiplap boards onto.

steps.headline: Prepare an existing wall.
steps.description: You want a clean, flat surface to install your shiplap wall over. Take down any wallpaper, for instance. Likewise, if there are any bulges in your wall, sand them down. Prime or paint the existing wall first if the current color will clash noticeably with the color you want the shiplap wall to be. This is because there will be small, usually unnoticeable gaps between the shiplap boards. For instance, if your current wall is purple and you want the shiplap to be white, prime or paint the existing wall white first. This will prevent tiny purple slivers from potentially showing through on the finished shiplap wall.

steps.headline: Measure your wall.
steps.description: Take your tape measure and run it along the bottom of the wall you want to cover, from one end to the other. Use the tape measure again to measure the height from the floor to the ceiling. Multiply these two numbers to get the area of your wall.

steps.headline: Gather your tools.
steps.description:
The basics of making a shiplap wall can be completed with a saw and nail gun or hammer. Still, a few other tools will make the job easier and your work more accurate. You'll already have several of these if you've been working on the wall, but make sure you have the following items:
Saw (optional)
Miter saw
Nail gun or hammer
Level
Stud finder
Pencil
Measuring tape

steps.headline: Get the necessary materials.
steps.description:
You can either purchase plywood and cut your own shiplap planks or buy the planks precut from a home improvement store. Or, you can use reclaimed wood flooring, barn wood, or pallet wood to create a shiplap wall. You’ll also need a few other supplies to fit the boards together and add the finishing touches. Head to a lumber supply store and get the following items:
Plywood (0.25 inches (0.64 cm)), precut shiplap planks, reclaimed wood flooring, barn wood, or pallet wood (enough to cover the wall)
Rounded trim molding
Corner molding
Baseboards (optional)
Nails
Sandpaper
Primer
Paint
Caulk
Nickels, popsicle sticks, or tile spacers

steps.headline: Cut the plywood into planks, if necessary.
steps.description: If you purchased plywood instead of precut shiplap planks, reclaimed wood flooring, barn wood, or pallet wood, cut the plywood into enough boards to cover the entire wall. Shiplap walls look best when made out of boards that are 6 inches (15 cm) to 8 inches (20 cm) wide. Sand the edges when you’re done. You can use a table saw to cut the plywood into planks of the correct size. However, most lumber supply stores will be happy to cut it for you, for free or a small cost.

steps.headline: Find the wall studs.
steps.description: Use your electric stud finder and mark all of the studs inside your wall. In many cases, these are 16 inches (41 cm) apart. Mark the center of each one with a vertical pencil line from floor to ceiling. This will serve as a guide for where to drive the nails in through the shiplap boards.

steps.headline: Check to see if your wall is level.
steps.description:
Place a carpenter's level at the top of your wall, parallel with the ceiling. Then, place it at the bottom of the wall, parallel with the floor. If your wall is majorly out of level, such as 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) or even 2 inches (5.1 cm), you still have an option:
Place the first plank at one end of the wall, just under the ceiling, then angle it up or down until it is level. Once you finish nailing in the boards on the first row, then cover the gap between the plank and the edge of the ceiling by nailing down trim. When you get to the last plank at the bottom of the wall that you can still fit level into place, nail it down. Then, nail down baseboard to cover up the gap between that plank and the floor. You can also use crown molding to cover any unevenness where the planks meet the ceiling. If the wall is really uneven, you may want to use crown molding in addition to a baseboard.

steps.headline: Put the first plank at the top of the wall.
steps.description: Place the first plank along the top left of the wall, just below the ceiling line. Drive in 2 nails through it at each stud, using the marks you made as a guide. Double check the level before and after nailing the plank.

steps.headline: Measure the length needed for the next plank.
steps.description: Unless your wall is very narrow, one plank probably won’t be enough to stretch from one side to the other. Measure the distance from the end of the first plank to the other side of the wall. Cut a plank to this length, and nail it in place.

steps.headline: Work down the wall, alternating between long and short planks.
steps.description: Apply another plank just under the first row, with its end against the right of the wall. Nail it in place, and then cut another plank to a shorter length to cover the left side of the second row. Keep alternating between long and short planks in this pattern, to give your shiplap wall a nice staggered pattern. Place nickels, popsicle sticks, or tile spacers turned on their sides between each row of planks. These will serve as a spacer so that the boards will be able to expand and contract without warping. Remove the spacers when you’re done. Use a level now and then to check and make sure the rows are even. If they’re not, angle the next row very slightly to make it more parallel with the floor and ceiling.

steps.headline: Deal with obstructions in the wall.
steps.description: There may be times when you run into something, like a window or door, that prevents you from running long planks from one end of the wall to the other. In general, you can just shorten the boards accordingly to fit around this obstruction. If there's an electrical outlet in the wall, turn off the power to the outlet. Unscrew and pull out the outlet from the wall without disconnecting the wires. Install the shiplap carefully with the outlet out. Then, reinstall the outlet using longer screws so it is flush with the shiplap instead of recessed into it.

steps.headline: Add a baseboard, if desired.
steps.description: You can run shiplap boards all the way down to the floor. If you prefer, however, you can nail a baseboard on the bottom of the wall, running along the floor. Any standard baseboard will be fine.

steps.headline: Install molding along the corners.
steps.description: If you are shiplapping several walls, use quarter round molding where one wall runs into the other. If the walls run around a corner, use L-shaped molding to cover the joints. Simply measure from floor to ceiling, cut molding to this length, and nail it in place.

steps.headline: Fill in any gaps with caulk.
steps.description: Use a caulk pump gun. Fill in any cracks or blemishes in the wood. You do not need to fill in the spaces between the planks. However, you can caulk the edges of the molding if there are gaps.

steps.headline: Paint or stain the wall.
steps.description: If you want to paint the wall, first apply a coat of primer, and then at least one coat of your desired color. Add another coat if necessary. If you want to stain the wall, cover the planks and molding in at least one coat of stain. Seal the stained wall with polyurethane, an oil finish, or another product if desired.
